definition: to take unfair advantage of/to deceive/to cheat
see 壓根兒|压根儿[ya4 gen1 r5]
to press/to push down/to keep under (control)/pressure

sentences.english: Why must I go about mourning, oppressed by the enemy?
sentences.chinese: 我爲何因仇敵的欺壓時常哀痛呢？

sentences.english: Oppressing The Masses, Could This Be.
Youths oppress my people, women rule over them.
sentences.chinese: 至於我的百姓，孩童欺壓他們，婦女轄管他們。

sentences.english: And, above all, no animal must ever tyrannise over his own kind.
sentences.chinese: 而且，千萬要注意，任何動物都不能欺壓自己的同類。

sentences.english: Even that did not stop other police officers from abusing their powers or relishing in their bully-boy tactics.
sentences.chinese: 即使如此，也無法阻止警察繼續濫權和欺壓人民。

sentences.english: This idiom means relying on another 's power to bully or frighten others.
sentences.chinese: 這個成語用來比喻依仗別人的勢力去欺壓人或嚇唬人。

sentences.english: As for my people, children are their oppressors, and women rule over them.
sentences.chinese: 至於我的百姓，孩童欺壓他們，婦女管轄他們。

sentences.english: The devil does not ride us any more.
sentences.chinese: 現在，那災星再也不來欺壓我們。

sentences.english: Moreover I have seen how the Egyptians oppress them.
sentences.chinese: 我也看見埃及人怎樣欺壓他們。

sentences.english: The strong should not tyrannize the weak.
Wickedness is in the midst thereof: deceit and guile depart not from her streets.
sentences.chinese: 邪惡在其中，欺壓和詭詐不離街市。

sentences.english: The landlord was always lording it over the peasants .
At the time she was leading God's people, they were under the oppression of Jabin, a king of Canaan.
sentences.chinese: 當她領導以色列人時，他們正受到迦南王耶賓的欺壓。

sentences.english: The powerful lords were guilty of grinding the villagers under their heels.
sentences.chinese: 那些大領主的罪過是以權勢欺壓村民。

sentences.english: He who oppresses the poor to increase his wealth and he who gives gifts to the rich-both come to poverty. Sayings of the Wise
sentences.chinese: 欺壓貧窮爲要利己的，並送禮與富戶的，都必缺乏。

sentences.english: Hazael king of Aram oppressed Israel throughout the reign of Jehoahaz.
sentences.chinese: 約哈斯年間，亞蘭王哈薛屢次欺壓以色列人。

definition: to condemn in speech and in writing (idiom)/to denounce by word and pen
to submit to humiliation (idiom); to suffer in silence/to swallow one's anger/to grin and bear it
to crowd out/to push aside/to supplant
to drag sb before a public meeting to denounce, humiliate and physically abuse them (esp. during the Cultural Revolution)
to view sb as an enemy/to be hateful towards
to gesticulate/to point out/to point the finger of blame
